title: The Download: attempting to track AI, and the next generation of nuclear power
summary: This is todayâ€™s edition of The Download, our weekday newsletter that provides a daily dose of whatâ€™s going on in the world of technology. This is the most misunderstood graph in AI Every time OpenAI, Google, or Anthropic drops a new frontier large language model, the AI community holds its breath. â€¦
body: This is today’s edition of The Download , our weekday newsletter that provides a daily dose of what’s going on in the world of technology. This is the most misunderstood graph in AI Every time OpenAI, Google, or Anthropic drops a new frontier large language model, the AI community holds its breath. It doesnâ€™t exhale until METR, an AI research nonprofit whose name stands for â€œModel Evaluation & Threat Research,â€ updates a now-iconic graph that has played a major role in the AI discourse since it was first released in March of last year.  The graph suggests that certain AI capabilities are developing at an exponential rate, and more recent model releases have outperformed that already impressive trend. That was certainly the case for Claude Opus 4.5, the latest version of Anthropicâ€™s most powerful model, which was released in late November. In December, METR announced that Opus 4.5 appeared to be capable of independently completing a task that would have taken a human about five hoursâ€”a vast improvement over what even the exponential trend would have predicted. But the truth is more complicated than those dramatic responses would suggest. Read the full story . â€”â€¦

title: Three questions about next-generation nuclear power, answered
summary: Nuclear power continues to be one of the hottest topics in energy today, and in our recent online Roundtables discussion about next-generation nuclear power, hyperscale AI data centers, and the grid, we got dozens of great audience questions. These ran the gamut, and while we answered quite a few (â€¦
body: Nuclear power continues to be one of the hottest topics in energy today, and in our recent online Roundtables discussion about next-generation nuclear power , hyperscale AI data centers , and the grid, we got dozens of great audience questions. These ran the gamut, and while we answered quite a few (and Iâ€™m keeping some in mind for future reporting), there were a bunch we couldnâ€™t get to, at least not in the depth I would have liked. So letâ€™s answer a few of your questions about advanced nuclear power. Iâ€™ve combined similar ones and edited them for clarity. How are the fuel needs for next-generation nuclear reactors different, and how are companies addressing the supply chain? Many next-generation reactors donâ€™t use the low-enriched uranium used in conventional reactors. Itâ€™s worth looking at high-assay low-enriched uranium, or HALEU, specifically. This fuel is enriched to higher concentrations of fissile uranium than conventional nuclear fuel, with a proportion of the isotope U-235 that falls between 5% and 20%. (In conventional fuel, itâ€™s below 5%.) HALEU can be produced with the same technology as low-enriched uranium, but the geopolitics are complicated. Today, Russia basicallâ€¦

body: MIT Technology Review Explains: Let our writers untangle the complex, messy world of technology to help you understand whatâ€™s coming next. You can read more from the series here . Every time OpenAI, Google, or Anthropic drops a new frontier large language model, the AI community holds its breath. It doesnâ€™t exhale until METR, an AI research nonprofit whose name stands for â€œModel Evaluation & Threat Research,â€ updates a now-iconic graph that has played a major role in the AI discourse since it was first released in March of last year. The graph suggests that certain AI capabilities are developing at an exponential rate, and more recent model releases have outperformed that already impressive trend. That was certainly the case for Claude Opus 4.5, the latest version of Anthropicâ€™s most powerful model, which was released in late November. In December, METR announced that Opus 4.5 appeared to be capable of independently completing a task that would have taken a human about five hoursâ€”a vast improvement over what even the exponential trend would have predicted. One Anthropic safety researcher tweeted that he would change the direction of his research in light of those results; anotâ€¦

title: The Download: the future of nuclear power plants, and social media-fueled AI hype
summary: This is todayâ€™s edition of The Download, our weekday newsletter that provides a daily dose of whatâ€™s going on in the world of technology. Why AI companies are betting on next-gen nuclear AI is driving unprecedented investment for massive data centers and an energy supply that can support its huge câ€¦
body: This is today’s edition of The Download , our weekday newsletter that provides a daily dose of what’s going on in the world of technology. Why AI companies are betting on next-gen nuclear AI is driving unprecedented investment for massive data centers and an energy supply that can support its huge computational appetite. One potential source of electricity for these facilities is next-generation nuclear power plants , which could be cheaper to construct and safer to operate than their predecessors. We recently held a subscriber-exclusive Roundtables discussion on hyperscale AI data centers and next-gen nuclear â€”two featured technologies on the MIT Technology Review 10 Breakthrough Technologies of 2026 list . You can watch the conversation back here , and donâ€™t forget to subscribe to make sure you catch future discussions as they happen. title: Microbes could extract the metal needed for cleantech
summary: In a pine forest on Michiganâ€™s Upper Peninsula, the only active nickel mine in the US is nearing the end of its life. body: In a pine forest on Michiganâ€™s Upper Peninsula, the only active nickel mine in the US is nearing the end of its life. At a time when carmakers want the metal for electric-vehicle batteries, nickel concentration at Eagle Mine is falling and could soon drop too low to warrant digging. But earlier this year, the mineâ€™s owner started testing a new process that could eke out a bit more nickel. In a pair of shipping containers recently installed at the mineâ€™s mill, a fermentation-derived broth developed by the startup Allonnia is mixed with concentrated ore to capture and remove impurities. The process allows nickel production from lower-quality ore.  Kent Sorenson, Allonniaâ€™s chief technology officer, says this approach could help companies continue operating sites that, like Eagle Mine, have burned through their best ore. â€œThe low-hanging fruit is to keep mining the mines that we have,â€ he says.  Demand for nickel, copper, and rare earth elements is rapidly increasing amid the explosive growth of metal-intensive data centers, electric cars, and renewable energy projects. But producing these metals is becoming harder and more expensive because miners have already exploited thâ€¦

title: What weâ€™ve been getting wrong about AIâ€™s truth crisis
summary: This story originally appeared in The Algorithm, our weekly newsletter on AI. To get stories like this in your inbox first, sign up here. What would it take to convince you that the era of truth decay we were long warned aboutâ€”where AI content dupes us, shapes our beliefs even when we catch the lieâ€¦
body: This story originally appeared in The Algorithm, our weekly newsletter on AI. To get stories like this in your inbox first,  sign up here . What would it take to convince you that the era of truth decay we were long warned aboutâ€”where AI content dupes us, shapes our beliefs even when we catch the lie, and erodes societal trust in the processâ€”is now here? A story I published last week pushed me over the edge. It also made me realize that the tools we were sold as a cure for this crisis are failing miserably.  On Thursday, I reported the first confirmation that the US Department of Homeland Security, which houses immigration agencies, is using AI video generators from Google and Adobe to make content that it shares with the public. The news comes as immigration agencies have flooded social media with content to support President Trump’s mass deportation agendaâ€”some of which appears to be made with AI (like a video about â€œChristmas after mass deportationsâ€). But I received two types of reactions from readers that may explain just as much about the epistemic crisis weâ€™re in.  One was from people who werenâ€™t surprised, because on January 22 the White House had postâ€¦

title: The crucial first step for designing a successful enterprise AI system
summary: Many organizations rushed into generative AI, only to see pilots fail to deliver value. Now, companies want measurable outcomesâ€”but how do you design for success? body: Many organizations rushed into generative AI, only to see pilots fail to deliver value . Now, companies want measurable outcomesâ€”but how do you design for success? At Mistral AI, we partner with global industry leaders to co-design tailored AI solutions that solve their most difficult problems. Whether itâ€™s increasing CX productivity with Cisco , building a more intelligent car with Stellantis , or accelerating product innovation with ASML , we start with open frontier models and customize AI systems to deliver impact for each companyâ€™s unique challenges and goals. Our methodology starts by identifying an iconic use case, the foundation for AI transformation that sets the blueprint for future AI solutions. Choosing the right use case can mean the difference between true transformation and endless tinkering and testing. Identifying an iconic use case Mistral AI has four criteria that we look for in a use case: strategic, urgent, impactful, and feasible. First, the use case must be strategically valuable, addressing a core business process or a transformative new capability. It needs to be more than an optimization; it needs to be a gamechanger. The use case needs to be strategic enâ€¦

body: This is today’s edition of The Download , our weekday newsletter that provides a daily dose of what’s going on in the world of technology. Inside the marketplace powering bespoke AI deepfakes of real women Civitaiâ€”an online marketplace for buying and selling AI-generated content, backed by the venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitzâ€”is letting users buy custom instruction files for generating celebrity deepfakes. Some of these files were specifically designed to make pornographic images banned by the site, a new analysis has found. The study, from researchers at Stanford and Indiana University, looked at peopleâ€™s requests for content on the site, called â€œbounties.â€ The researchers found that between mid-2023 and the end of 2024, most bounties asked for animated contentâ€”but a significant portion were for deepfakes of real people, and 90% of these deepfake requests targeted women. Read the full story . â€”James O’Donnell Whatâ€™s next for EV batteries in 2026 Demand for electric vehicles and the batteries that power them has never been hotter. In 2025, EVs made up over a quarter of new vehicle sales globally, up from less than 5% in 2020. Some regions are seeing even â€¦

title: Tactics, transfers and turmoil - inside the fall of Amorim
summary: After 14 months, Ruben Amorim has been sacked by Manchester United - but where did it all go wrong?

title: Booze, beach, beaten - how England lost the Ashes
summary: BBC Sport chief cricket reporter Stephan Shemilt reveals the inside story of England's Ashes defeat in Australia on and off the pitch.

title: I've realised I can make a difference - Hoy
summary: In a new BBC documentary, Sir Chris Hoy shows how he is using his Olympic mindset to reframe his purpose following a terminal cancer diagnosis.

title: Inside McLaren's season - the rules, values, incidents & relationships
summary: Intra-team title battles turn toxic far more often than not. Andrew Benson analyses how McLaren have maintained relative harmony between Lando Norris and Oscar Piastri.
